thread.title: The Ashes 2015: Michael Clarke draws World Cup parallels as Aussies look to bounce back | The
thread.title_full: The Ashes 2015: Michael Clarke draws World Cup parallels as Aussies look to bounce back | The Advertiser

author: Ben Horne in Cardiff
title: The Ashes 2015: Michael Clarke draws World Cup parallels as Aussies look to bounce back | The
text:
MICHAEL Clarke says Australia must draw inspiration from the way they turned the tables on New Zealand in the World Cup, as they attempt to resurrect their Ashes campaign on Thursday at Lord’s.
Having been completely outplayed in every facet by a hungry and energetic England in the first Test in Cardiff, Australia now have just four days to bounce back and save another Ashes tour from slipping away as it has every trip for the past 14 years.
Australia received a frightening wake-up call just three matches into the World Cup earlier this year when they were rolled for just 151 runs and had their pants pulled down by New Zealand at Eden Park.
Michael Clarke has plenty to ponder after Australia’s heavy defeat. Source: Getty Images
UNDER PRESSURE: Watson and Haddin facing the axe
HEAVY LOSS: Aussies cop battering from Poms
AS IT HAPPENED: relive our live blog
Following that setback, Australia didn’t falter again and on World Cup final day when it mattered most, they romped to victory over the Black Caps.
If Australia are to take heart from that parallel – it’s interesting to note that Shane Watson and an injured fast bowler were immediately dropped from the line-up for the next match.
The same kind of shake-up could happen here with Watson fighting to save his Test career after another underwhelming performance and Mitchell Starc (ankle) racing the clock to prove his fitness.
Clarke says the short-turnaround will help the rattled Australians respond to their wake-up call as they did after their belting at Eden Park.
“This is a completely different team but I think any time you get outplayed it makes you see and understand where you have to get to beat your opposition,” he said.
Not even a swahbuckling innings from Mitchell Johnson could save the Aussies. Source: Getty Images
“We certainly haven’t taken England lightly and we knew they were going to come out and be tough to beat in these conditions and now we’ve just had a real taste of that.
“The advantage and the positive for us is we’re only four days away from the second Test.
“I think that’s a good thing for this team.
“All the boys now, like losing to New Zealand in the World Cup gave us a bit of a kick up the backside, they’ll probably see this game very similar.
“This gives us a bit of a kick up the backside and we look forward to the second Test match.”
Clarke admits had Joe Root’s edge through to Brad Haddin gone to hand when England were in major trouble at 3-43 on day one – the entire course of the Test match could have changed.
The Poms celebrate their big win. Source: AFP
However, the skipper said there could be no blame levelled at Haddin whatsoever because Australia had the rest of the Test match to make up for the mistake and failed.
He said in fielding, bowling and batting – Australia failed on every count.
“If we hung onto our catches it could have been a whole different story,” he said.
“But it’s not just about one catch. I’ve played this game long enough to know that you get to bowl to the other players, you get more opportunities to bowl to the guy you dropped, you get a chance to walk out and bat as well twice.
“(Root) went on and made a good hundred and played really well but I think our standard in the field has been exceptional over the past couple of years.
“We’ve caught really well. Sometimes you drop them and sometimes you pay for it. In this case we’ve paid for it.”
How the Aussies could have done with Ryan Harris. Source: Getty Images
Watson went wicket-less in the match and failed to kick on with starts during both of his visits to the crease.
It’s an all-too common story for the 34-year-old all-rounder, as was the fact he fell both times lbw – to make it an astonishing 29 times out that way for his career.
Clarke said Watson’s demeanour remained strong.
“I think Watto is doing what Watto does. Working extremely hard to try and be successful,” said Clarke.
“Shane is an extremely hard worker, he wants to have success like the rest of us.
“I think it’s the hardest part of this game - the longer you play the more ups and downs you go through.
Shane Watson dismissed LBW again against England 0:38 Play video
Shane Watson dismissed for LBW for the 14th time in 35 innings against England.
Fox Sports 12 Jul 2015 Sport/Cricket/Ashes/Highlights
“When things aren’t going to plan you’ve got to stick to your processes, work hard, cop a few smacks on the chin and keep backing your own ability.
“I think that’s exactly what Watto is doing.
“He’s been a big part of the Australian cricket team in all three formats and has had a lot of success as well.”
Originally published as Clarke: this gives us a kick up the backside
